Award.AwardTitle: Searching for the Bottom of the Initial Mass Function
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support an observational survey to find lowest mass objects formed in areas of recent star formation. A principal goal is to uncover the initial mass function (IMF), which is the distribution of stellar/substellar objects over mass. This will be done through analysis of optical and infrared photometry from wide-field surveys and followup spectroscopy of candidate substellar objects (brown dwarfs and planetary-mass objects) identified in those data.

The project is expected to (1) test theories of star formation, which make different predictions for the minimum mass of the IMF and its dependence on star-forming conditions; (2) constrain the possible mechanisms for the formation of planetary-mass companions; and (3) enable estimates of the frequency of giant planets that have been ejected from planetary systems based on microlensing detections of free-floating Jupiter-mass bodies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have used optical and infrared images from ground- and space-based telescopes to search for the least massive brown dwarfs in the nearest clouds of gas and dust that are giving birth to new stars. The goal of this work is to better to determine the lowest mass at which brown dwarfs exist, where a brown dwarf is a star-like body that is too small in mass and too cool to fuse hydrogen, which makes it very dim. Through our work, we have discovered dozens of new brown dwarfs, some of which are among the least massive brown dwarfs that have been found anywhere with masses of only 5 times the mass of Jupiter. One of these brown dwarfs is also the least massive brown dwarf to have a disk of gas and dust around it, which may be capable of producing planets one day. We conclude that additional observations with larger telescopes are needed to determine whether brown dwarfs exist below 5 Jupiter masses. Undergraduate and graduate students in astronomy were trained in research through this project. In addition, we incorporated the results of this research into workshops for middle and high school science teachers and short courses ("elderhostels") on astronomy for members of the public older than 55.
